purpose_overview.goal: Support muscle hypertrophy while controlling fat gain by emphasizing higher dietary fats and moderate carbohydrates
purpose_overview.approach: Moderate caloric surplus (10–15%) with 35–40% of calories from fat and carbs at 3–4 g/kg/day
best_for: Individuals prone to fat gain on high-carb bulks
Endomorph body types or those with lower carbohydrate tolerance
Athletes in sports or phases where glycogen demand is moderate (e.g., strength-focused blocks)
scientific_basis: Higher fat intake maintains anabolic hormones like testosterone
Provides calorie density for appetite control
Reduces insulin spikes for carb-sensitive individuals

caloric_strategy.maintenance_calculation: Estimate TDEE via Mifflin-St Jeor or Cunningham equation

rationale.protein: Supports muscle protein synthesis (Morton et al., 2018)
rationale.carbohydrates: Sufficient for glycogen replenishment without excessive spikes
rationale.fats: Supports hormones and increases caloric density (Volek et al., 2015)

pre_workout.2_3_hours_before: Moderate carbs + lean protein, small amounts of healthy fats

meal_timing_distribution.post_workout: Within 2 hr: 20–40 g protein + 0.8–1 g/kg carbs

supplements_optional.name: Vitamin D
supplements_optional.note: Beneficial if sun exposure is limited

monitoring_adjustments.body_weight: Track weekly; adjust surplus if gain exceeds 0.5%/week
monitoring_adjustments.energy_levels: Increase carbs slightly if workouts feel sluggish
monitoring_adjustments.body_composition: Evaluate every 4–6 weeks for fat gain

advantages: Better suited for those who gain fat quickly on high-carb diets
Higher fat intake can improve appetite control and hormone support
Easier to hit calorie targets for people with smaller appetites
limitations: Lower carb intake may reduce performance for very high-volume training
Requires careful fat source selection to maintain cardiovascular health
Muscle glycogen replenishment may be slower after intense sessions
references: Morton RW et al. (2018). Br J Sports Med, 52(6):376-384.
Volek JS et al. (2015). J Strength Cond Res, 29(1):100-107.
Kerksick CM et al. (2017). J Int Soc Sports Nutr, 14:33.
American College of Sports Medicine (2022). Nutrition and Athletic Performance Position Stand.
